item.title: Changing Adventure URLs
item.description: I'm making a few changes to the Adventures blog. Most significantly, the blog post URLs are changing, dropping dates in favor of simple titles.

item.title: Automatically Incrementing Sequence Numbers
item.description: Notenik offers three slightly different approaches to adding Notes in sequence, such that Notenik will automatically increment your Seq values as you go.

item.title: Outlining with Notenik
item.description: Notenik has two special metadata fields — Seq and Level — that can easily be used to structure a collection of notes into an outline.

item.title: Formatting a Quote Attribution with Notenik 15.0.0
item.description: This latest release of Notenik now provides a handy new Markdown extension that can be used to nicely format an attribution line following a blockquote.

item.title: Leveraging Commonplace Entries
item.description: Once you have a commonplace book, what can you do with it? Here's where all that hard work pays off, if you're using Notenik.

item.title: Commonplace Data
item.description: Once you've committed to starting a commonplace book, and then decided to store your book in plain text files formatted with Markdown, then the next question is: what data do you want to collect as part of each entry?

item.title: Storage Medium for a Commonplace Book
item.description: Once you've committed to starting a commonplace book, your first question will be: how should I store it? I think there's really only one good answer here.

item.title: Commonplacing with Notenik
item.description: As one reviewer on the US Mac App Store says, Notenik “is flexible enough to fit any number of use cases, from the simple to the complex.” But certainly one of my core use cases for Notenik is storage of a commonplace book.

item.title: Eating My Own Dogfood
item.description: I'll tell you a little secret – even if no one else in the world was using Notenik, I would still continue to work on it, just because I want to use it.

item.title: Let's Talk Metadata
item.description: Let's talk metadata for a minute. You might call it front matter. But Notenik has supported such fields for over ten years, and has a rich set of functionality to make use of this info.

item.title: Custom Display Mode
item.description: Notenik 14.9.0 adds a new custom display mode.

item.title: Mac Menus
item.description: There are some nice side benefits to Notenik's use of traditional Mac menus.

item.title: Three Types of Merge Templates
item.description: Notenik supports essentially three different types of merge templates. Learn what each one is used for, and how they differ from one another.

item.title: Use Merge Templates to Format Output
item.description: Merge Templates are one of Notenik's most powerful features, because they allow you to easily format the data in your Notes into any output format that can be expressed within a text file. HTML, XML, JSON, CSV, tab-delimited and plain text files can all be generated easily, whenever you like.

item.title: Cross-Posting to Mastodon
item.description: It's taken a few tries to get this working but from now on I believe all of the Adventures with Notenik blog posts (starting with this one!) should be automatically cross-posting to @notenik@mastodon.social.

item.description: An Atom feed is another kind of web feed that you can use on your site. This is newer than RSS, and is also XML-based.
